title: 105_hr2057
content: The Act titled "National Voter Opportunity To Inform Congress Effectively on a Flat Tax and a Cap on Tax Increases Act of 1997" is abbreviated as National VOICE on a Flat Tax and Cap on Tax Increases Act of 1997. The Congress finds that the right to vote is fundamental, citizens should have a voice in Congress, and there is a demand for less taxation. The Act aims to allow citizens to voice their opinion on a flat income tax system and require a majority vote to raise taxes. The Act aims to allow citizens to voice their opinion on a flat income tax system and require a majority vote to raise taxes. Additionally, it proposes a national nonbinding referendum on a flat tax on income and a national vote on tax increases at the 1998 general election to study the feasibility of conducting similar referenda on other important issues in the future. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "nonbinding referendum" as advisory questions on a flat tax and national vote on tax increases, to be included in the 1998 general election. The agency in each State and territory is responsible for conducting general elections within its jurisdiction. SEC. 4. PROCEDURES FOR NATIONAL VOTER OPPORTUNITY TO INFORM CONGRESS ON A FLAT TAX AND REQUIRING A NATIONAL VOTE ON TAX INCREASES NONBINDING REFERENDUM. This Act places advisory questions on the 1998 general election ballot in every congressional district, delegate and/or resident commissioner district, in the United States, the District of Columbia, and the territories. The Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate certify ballot title and questions by June 30, 1998. The national advisory referendum on a flat tax on income and requiring a national vote on tax increases will be included in the 1998 general election ballot. The 1998 general election ballot will include advisory questions on a flat tax rate on income and a constitutional amendment for a majority vote on tax increases. Ballots will be prepared following the same procedures as elections for Congress members. The bill authorizes $5,000,000 for states to be reimbursed for costs incurred in placing nonbinding referendum questions on the 1998 general election ballot. Reimbursements will be made from Congress' franking accounts. The bill authorizes $5,000,000 for states to be reimbursed for costs incurred in placing nonbinding referendum questions on the 1998 general election ballot. The Clerk of the United States House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate will ensure proper application and reimbursement of expenses. State election agencies will tabulate and certify voting results similar to elections for Members of Congress. Certified results will be transmitted to Congress, Members, and Judiciary Committees. The official election results of nonbinding referenda will be certified by the State election agency to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate. Results will be transmitted to Members of Congress and reviewed by the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance for recommendations. Within 6 months of the general election, recommendations for response will be reported back to the full House and Senate. State election agencies must provide comments on procedures for future nonbinding referenda within 90 days of the election, which will be forwarded to the respective committees on the Judiciary of the House of Representatives and Senate. The Act will be effective upon its enactment.
